nova/tests/functional/test_server_faults.message: I don't understand why this change is needed (but I can see that it is locally). What is it about the presence of the filter that makes it fail? I would have thought that if placement returned a host with enough DISK_GB, then the DiskFilter would pass that host as well. But it doesn't.

Looks like the hypervisor reports 0 disk:

2019-08-09 17:28:30,512 DEBUG [nova.scheduler.host_manager] Update host state from compute node: ComputeNode(cpu_allocation_ratio=16.0,cpu_info='{"arch": "x86_64", "model": "Nehalem", "vendor": "Intel", "features": ["pge", "clflush"], "topology": {"cores": 1, "threads": 1, "sockets": 4}}',created_at=2019-08-09T17:28:27Z,current_workload=0,deleted=False,deleted_at=None,disk_allocation_ratio=1.0,disk_available_least=0,free_disk_gb=1028,free_ram_mb=7680,host='compute',host_ip=10.0.2.15,hypervisor_hostname='fake-mini',hypervisor_type='fake',hypervisor_version=1000,id=1,local_gb=1028,local_gb_used=0,memory_mb=8192,memory_mb_used=512,metrics='[]',numa_topology=None,pci_device_pools=PciDevicePoolList,ram_allocation_ratio=1.5,running_vms=0,service_id=None,stats={},supported_hv_specs=[HVSpec],updated_at=2019-08-09T17:28:27Z,uuid=31bda4dc-878f-493a-877a-9f3a61c11d1e,vcpus=1,vcpus_used=0)

and DiskFilter says there's 0 disk:

2019-08-09 17:28:30,515 DEBUG [nova.scheduler.filters.disk_filter] (compute, fake-mini) ram: 7680MB disk: 0MB io_ops: 0 instances: 0 does not have 20480 MB usable disk, it only has 0.0 MB usable disk.

This looks like some kind of reporting issue and unrelated to how the DiskFilter works... But if so, how are any other func tests passing if compute has 0 disk all the time? Weird.
Thanks for the sanity check. In isolation, the code comment and filter removal didn't make sense to me as to why it would help.

This isn't new in Ocata functional tests, I copied it from another test. I would have to dig into the failures to come up with a better reason. My guess is maybe some weirdness in how the compute reports available disk or the DiskFilter calculates it compared to how placement gets it. This test is using the SmallFakeDriver which reports 1028 GB of local disk and the allocation ration should be 1.0 so total disk reported to placement should be 1028GB. And the flavor we're using should be the first one created by the DefaultFlavorsFixture, which requires 1GB of disk:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/ocata/nova/tests/fixtures.py#L557

So yeah, I'd have to re-enable the filter, make things fail and check the logs to see what's going on. Regardless, like I said, lots of other tests are doing the same thing and if we're using placement we don't need the DiskFilter anyway, we were just late to remove the ram/core/disk filters from the default list of enabled filters until Pike (or maybe we did it in pike b/c the ocata scheduler still had compat for computes not yet using placement).

I was confused first so just to be sure: Will there be always a migration where the uuids match (the active migration)?

Yeah the migration record is created in the source cell DB when the migration starts, e.g.:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/1316c1c2850d2f966f335b628f7f5fe88cef611c/nova/conductor/tasks/migrate.py#L152

So here we're copying that and creating it in the target cell DB. Since the new migration record in the target cell DB will have a different id (or could), everything that needs to access the migration uniquely needs to do it via the migration uuid. That comes into play a bit later here:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/636224/29/nova/compute/api.py

There is also some related work done during the prep-at-dest work here:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/627890/41/nova/conductor/tasks/cross_cell_migrate.py@502

Do we have any insurance that the instance data does not change in the source cell while we are doing the copy?

An extreme edge case example: While / After we are creating the copy somebody deletes the port in neutron bound to this instance. Neutron will send os-external-event that is routed to the source compute and the vif is detached from the running instance and deleted. So the data we read from L114 become stale.
OK, non-None task_state helps with the majority of the cases. And I agree that my example was extreme.

> Do we have any insurance that the instance data does not change in
 > the source cell while we are doing the copy?

A non-None task_state is about the most insurance we can get anywhere in nova that when we're doing something on an instance, another task can't be changing it concurrently.

 > An extreme edge case example: While / After we are creating the
 > copy somebody deletes the port in neutron bound to this instance.
 > Neutron will send os-external-event that is routed to the source
 > compute and the vif is detached from the running instance and
 > deleted. So the data we read from L114 become stale.

Sure, like you say that's extreme, but could happen in a tight window. However, I'd argue that's already a problem for *any* move operation we have where we've pulled the network info cache data at t0, it changes on another thread at t1, and then we use the data from t0 at t2 and there is an issue.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
As a workaround you could use microversion 2.56 and request a specific host for the cold migration.

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/api-microversion-history.html#id51

I think this has been fixed:

Ie4f9177f4d54cbc7dbcf58bd107fd5f24c60d8bb

There are other ways to fix this to intelligently filter the host based on the capabilities of the compute service on which the instance is running, see:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666604/

Clearly there are several bugs related to this same issue:

- bug 1811235
- bug 1819216
- bug 1748697

If we thought through this with what the most flexible solution would be then we don't have to deal with one-off solutions like the one proposed in this patch. Doing that properly requires some discussion in the mailing list though to get people aligned on the direction to take.

openstack/cloud/openstackcloud.py.message: So, is discovery_cache attached to cloud_config or a session?

Yes!

There can be a discovery cache on the auth plugin, on the session, and there can be one passed directly to the discovery function. Any that exist are consulted, and results are saved to any that exist.

The thing is - we really want to be super aggressive with discovery cache, because it's completely unauthenticated data that isn't related to scope - so it doesn't change per user or project. So we make a discovery cache dict in CloudRegion and pass it to Session - so that we can make sure we have one.

There's two potential issues (one I just thought of writing this, so thanks!)

First - we should probably make discovery_cache in loader.OpenStackConfig so that it's shared more globally - and so that it can naturally get passed to the new CloudRegion created from it.

Second - most of the service projects (nova, ironic) likely won't have a loader.OpenStackConfig, as they'll likely just be creating a CloudRegion directly - like if they used cloud_region.from_conf. In that case, in this method when we create a new CloudRegion, there's no where to pull it from except the old one - or from the old session, like we're doing here.

So for completeness we should probably get around to doing the First thinng... but the Second thing handles both cases from a connect_as perspective, and we need to do it for the second case anyway... so I'm inclined to ignore the first one for now.

That said - I should rename these vars to cloud_region because it's otherwise somewhat confusing to remember what they are ...

keystone/models/token_model.py.message:
This can only be done for non-federated users until we have renewable app-creds. The reason is to avoid the scenario where a user comes in with an assertion that grants a group to the user and the user creates an app-cred to circumvent losing access to the group on a re-auth (loss of the group in the assertion from the IDP).

So, this needs to check if the user is a federated user and set "effective=True" only in the case when the user is not federated.

This can just be a set, we don't need it to be a list. order doesn't really matter, a set comprehension would be sufficient:

    {x['role_id'] for x in assignment_list}

If you don't want a set-comprehension:

   set([x['role_id'] for x in assignment_list])

This also will be faster lookup(s) than the list scan on line 419 (only matters in really large sets of roles)

NIT: No need for the outer {} in this case, it is already a set. Either use:

  {x['role_id'] for x in assignment_list}

or

  set([x['role_id'] for x in assignment_list])
This isn't really fixing anything yet. Can we partially fix it setting effective=True for non-federated users?
Part of the issue is that detecting all the forms of federated users was not clear. This is aligning code so that the change can be a minimal fix.

keystone/tests/unit/test_v3_federation.p.message: Should this test check to see if the effective roles include the group role, also shouldn't this fail because the user is granted access via the group not directly?

I would think that the app-cred should fail to create if you reference a group-supplied role. Can we either have this patch changed or a followup for the following:

1) Do setup (user/group)
2) Attempt to create an app-cred with a group-role, should fail to create (if this isn't an API break)
3) Add direct role to user (duplicating group role)
4) Create App Cred (success)
5) Auth (success)
6) Remove direct assignment
7) App Cred needs to be invalidated *or* now auth should fail if app cred is not invalidated.


This simply is my expectation that the app-cred should communicate it is not going to work as early as possible.

With all of that said, I am not opposed to the current workflow, I need to review one more time before upgrading to +2.

Sure no problem, I need to review the tests
Although I think the API allows to create the credential :S

elements/haproxy-octavia/pre-install.d/0.message: We can't do this through pkg-map?

The way gentoo decides what to ALLOW to install is based on the package masks. We *do* choose this version in pkg-map, but unless we also unmask the version here, it will print an error and refuse to install it. Think of it as very similar to what the ubuntu line is doing, just enabling a repo, but it's for a single package...

swift/common/request_helpers.py.message:
It's interesting that this does title() while get_object_transient_sysmeta doesn't...

Fortunately all of the update headers should be ASCII, so I don't *think* https://review.opendev.org/#/c/664438/ should be a concern?

the test fall out was less doing the title than w/o - i don't really understand the concern with bytes/strings :'(

But if you're happy I'm happy!
Welcome to the wonderful world of Py3 strings :P ..esp when it comes to wsgi.
ok, I understand why *this* code is fine then at least

> i don't really understand the concern with bytes/strings :'(

.upper(), .lower(), and .title() behave very differently for unicode vs bytes, and it all gets worse with bytes-masquerading-as-unicode on py3:

 Python 3.7.4 (default, Jul  9 2019, 16:32:37) 
 [GCC 9.1.1 20190503 (Red Hat 9.1.1-1)] on linux
 Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
 >>> '\xdf'.lower()
 'ß'
 >>> '\xdf'.lower() == '\xdf'
 True
 >>> '\xdf'.upper()
 'SS'
 >>> '\xdf'.encode('utf8').decode('latin1')
 'Ã\x9f'
 >>> '\xdf'.encode('utf8').decode('latin1').lower()
 'ã\x9f'
 >>> '\xdf'.encode('utf8').decode('latin1').lower().encode('latin1').decode('utf8')
 Traceback (most recent call last):
   File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
 UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode bytes in position 0-1: unexpected end of data

Meanwhile,

 Python 2.7.16 (default, Apr 30 2019, 15:54:43) 
 [GCC 9.0.1 20190312 (Red Hat 9.0.1-0.10)] on linux2
 Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
 >>> '\xdf' == '\xdf'.upper() == '\xdf'.lower()
 True

TL;DR: when thinking about case-insensitive headers, we assume the range a-z is equivalent to A-Z, and there are no other equivalencies. Our normal tricks for dealing with it on py2 (str.upper, str.lower, str.title) don't map real cleanly to py3; they only work the way we want when

- we've got bytes, or
- we already *know* everything's ASCII.

nova/objects/build_request.py.message: This method is ridiculous, I know. I plan to split out exact filter matching, regex matching, and sorting. It was just easier to develop and test this way initially.

So this will break out of the loop from L235 and continue the outer loop at L234. It feels like we need to just have multiple return points, unfortunately. Otherwise it seems like it would get complicated trying to exit this function early without doing extra loops.
Returning here would be an optimization. Continuing the outer loop won't change the result since keep_instance can't be set back to True, but yeah we don't need to keep going here.
This will mean keep_instance = True. Is that intended?

So I totally read this wrong in the original code. The current code "short circuits" if it would have done "IN <empty set>", which I thought was basically ignoring that filter. I didn't catch that it was doing a return there instead of a break, which is a complete bail on the whole thing. Instead of ignoring that filter it bails entirely and immediately signals "no instances could possibly match this". I definitely did not get that when I read it the first time and figured the same as laski here I guess.

So yeah, I guess instead of break here you too can bail hard to the caller.

So I though it matched the behavior of what the instance query will do in http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#n2380 but after looking again I see that it does the opposite. Nice catch.

I was basing this off of http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#n2384 where the filter will still be checked even if the instance has no value for the filter_key.

If I wasn't attempting to copy current behavior then what you suggest would certainly be better.

I was thinking about this again and realized the existing code does in fact require that filter key is present before filtering value by the fact that it's done in two query.filter calls [1]. The first call will filter/keep only instances that match the key and the second call will filter/keep only instances that match the value. That is, only instances that match the key will make it past the first call, so it is required that both match to keep the instance.

So I think this does need to be something more like:

 if filter key in instance and instance[filter_key] not in filter_val:

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/51575f/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L2373-L2374

That code lines up with lines 232/233 above. This lines up with lines 2384/2385 in sqlalchemy/api.py which checks that the key is valid on the db model and then tests the value. But it never checks that the key is set on the instance, just that it's a valid column. In this case if it was not a valid field we would get an exception just as that code would in getattr.
I think I finally get this now -- the difference between the attribute being set vs existing at all. Thanks for your patience in explaining.

Thanks for the thorough review. I appreciate the scrutiny to make sure I'm not sneaking something in.

I had to spend some time to convince myself it was right originally because it's really an odd check. I don't think it's intentionally supported to check against an unset attribute, but then again much of the sorting/filtering code doesn't seem intentional :)
